Couldn't it just be that as the head and body grew larger and more powerful, arms became unnecessary to grab or hold on to prey? As such, arms got smaller and smaller. Isn't it possible that Theropods like T-Rex living at the end of the Cretaceous were in the process of losing their arms completely but never got to that point because of the extinction event? So, T-Rex didn't evolve small arms because they were an advantage; they were an intermediary stage toward losing them completely. If they had've survived, might we be digging up fossils of new, later Theropods that have no arms at all?
I need a T-Rex with scaly giant gorilla arms. That'd be a sight to see

Are we sure that we're even right about the arms in the first place? Like are 100% certain that those arms even belong to the T-Rex? Scientists have made some pretty ridiculous claims over the years, that we now know were utter nonsense. So how can be sure they're right about T-Rex having tiny arms?

Perhaps we aren't seeing the whole picture. These bony "arms" are simply the base part of some larger wing-like structures composed mostly of fleshy material that hasn't survived. Assuming - as we now do - that theropods are the ancestors of birds, it would follow that these small upper limbs are the ancestors of wings. Perhaps the bones are the base of some muscular appendages used to assist balance when running at speed; something with aerodynamic properties.

This theory doesn't make any sense unless all basal theropods ate in large groups and somehow selected for smaller limbs, since so many theropod groups like tyrannosaurids and abelisaurids had tiny arms. In fact, majungasaurus had even tinier arms than T. rex and yet we have direct evidence of cannibalism amongst them. And it's not like lions or komodo dragons or crocodilians or wolves or so on have especially small limbs, and they all eat in groups. It just makes more sense that they evolved smaller arms so they could grow larger and more powerful heads while still maintaining their horizontal bipedal stance.

I've never understood why this question has gotten so much traction for so long. Limbs becoming vestigial is a well-established aspect of evolution; why is that so hard to accept here? The fossil record shows that the t-rex evolved from smaller, more proportional therapods into the big-headed, small-armed creature we know. Clearly they were getting what they needed from a more bite-centric evolutionary path, and the forelimbs were superfluous (and frankly, increasing head weight that much without decreasing forelimb weight would have made the tail's job as counterweight all the more difficult). Plenty of vestigial things don't "evolve away" fully; you can find snakes today that still have tiny nubbins of limbs left, or blind creatures living in total darkness 24/7 that still have eyes. I just always inferred that the arms weren't for anything, they were just vestigial.

Interesting idea. None of the various hypotheses put forward are mutually exclusive as to why T-Rex arms are so proportionally small. Young T-Rex we now know filled a different ecological niche than the full sized adults. They were built quite differently, so much so that juvenile T-Rex were thought at one time to be a different species. What were the arms of juveniles like relative to their bodies? It seems to me juveniles were active hunters. They were lighter obviously and probably speedier, both to outrun prey, and predator. No doubt an adult would make a meal of a juvenile, but he’d have to catch one first. I think the full sized adults were probably primarily scavengers. A dead Sauropod would attract a lot of scavengers and the smaller scavengers would make way for the big ones. A pecking order is established and I imagine several T-Rex at the same carcass probably had dominance displays to establish who gets first dibs and to avoid violence and injury.

But if having small arms far apart was good for keeping out of the way of masticating teeth, this begs the question, "what were they useful for anyway?" I mean could they holds onto the carcass they were eating? Were they strong enough for that? Could they grasp anything at all? Or did their head get in the way of everything? Were their hands useful for scoring flesh to eat? Or did they eat like a lot of animals, without engaging their forelimbs? Were they even necessary for anything?

Nature hardly throws anything away but often repurposes it. We have a tiny appendix. In a rabbit, theirs is almost the same length as their colon and acts like a rumen of sorts. Ours, vestigial as it is, is part of the Gut-Associated Lymphatic Tissue (GALT), and some point to it as a reservoir of bacterial colonies to repopulate the gut after the gut loses them. (penicillin, anyone?)

True a few people have vestigial gills, but mostly people develop gills in the womb into eyes, ears, nose, and mouth. These features are still useful.

Did the Therapod forelimbs develop from some other feature in ancestors? Did they progress into something like the bones of wings?

Were they something that appeared in a diversity explosion and find a use (or not!) in subsequent aeons of generations?

To me, what they aren't isn't good enough. Where they originated and what they became is my quest for understanding.

Regarding the theory that small arms were less vulnerable than those of a large-armed T-Rex in a feeding frenzy is that no fossils of large-armed T-Rex have been found. Sure, it's a nice theory, but without evidence it isn't any more credible than the others. And here's another problem I have had with paleontology in general ... we have evidence in the fossil record of lots of critters, but has anyone discovered the ancestors of T-Rex? Or the apatosaurus? Or the Stegosaurus 150 million years before their time. I look at these skeletons and I have to wonder from where did they come? What is their lineage? We have found our own ancestors, which are, of course, considerably younger by millions of years than any dinosaur species, but we can put together a picture of what human evolution looks like. We can't do the same for dinosaurs.

I never really put much thought into the why, but now that it got me real thinking: have people brought up the idea that maybe t-rex needed to have small arms in order to keep a sense of balance between the hunched position and the two legged-movement?

It'd seem like one of the more obvious propositions given how the whole skeletal sets are structured; maybe in becoming bigger than velociraptors, t-rex had to have the front arm-to-body ratio even smaller so that they wouldn't keep falling off-balance?

Kangaroos also have a similar-ish build and similarly small front arm-to-body ratio, if at least in relation to velociraptors, so maybe it's not a far-fetched thing to give up on front arm mass in order to keep a sense of balance with such forward/hunched builds?

I'm not buying the 'small arms stay out of the way' theory. Awareness of the location of limbs that could be at risk of self-inflicted wounds would doubtless have been favorably selected for. I have wondered if we caught the arms on T-Rex and other theropods as they were vanishing, like some snakes having tiny vestigial legs. But, my favorite theory is that they are the fast slashing defense weapons of the T-Rex's massively exposed throat and chest. The reason is that even though possibly vestigial, they have highly developed slashing talons and remarkable range of motion. While the massive jaw and head are awesome and crushing, they are also inherently difficult to swiftly move. There's a lot of mass there to quickly change directions while a swift animal could quickly avoid and attack at the throat and torso. Those short arms with devastating talons would do the job.

The arms were a remnant of the evolutionary transition from the aquatic life to the terrestrial one.
So, they used the small arms for further optimizing the fast correction of the equilibrium at high running speeds.
Exactly like, for example, the dog does it with its tail.
The idea that their arms were small so they don't bite each other arms when they eat in groups doesn't keep, because we have the example of the crocodiles of these days that eat carcases in groups and fight each other while doing it. They don't have small, insignificant "arms" ( legs ). They use their arms to help in changing the direction when moving either on the ground or in the water.

I don't know anything about dinosaurs or biology, but nope - I don't buy it. That sounds like a ridiculous reason. So here is my uneducated guess:

Step 1 - Start with a small animal ( T-Rex ancestor ) that needs to reach up high AND move fast, for whatever reason. There are 3 ways that an animal can reach up high - long arms, long neck, or standing on hind legs. Of the 3 options, standing on hind legs develops joints and muscles that allow for bipedal running, which is fast. Animals that have long necks are not fast, and animals that have long arms are not fast unless fully bipedal like humans.

Step 2 - As a partial quadruped, it becomes easier to balance on hind legs if the animal has a longer and heavier tail.

Step 3 - Thousands or millions of years go by and the animal gains lots of mass for whatever reason. ( The small ancestor evolves into a larger and larger animal )

Step 4 - Given a large tail, large body, and bipedal motion, excessive forward mass becomes a problem.

Step 5 - An evolutionary tradeoff emerges - The animal can either have a larger head and smaller arms, or larger arms and smaller head, in order to balance the forward body mass with the rear tail for efficient bipedal locomotion.

Step 6 - Animals that evolve larger heads and smaller arms can have larger jaws which makes them more formidable while fighting with peers, and they can kill larger prey.

So my personal conclusion is that a huge bipedal animal with small arms can maintain balance with a larger head. Big head is more useful than big arms for a predator.

I suspect that T. rex arm to leg ratio may not have been as disproportionate in younger specimens. I saw something a while back where they had been wondering about what appeared to be a gap in mid-range predators and only recently figured out that that gap would have been filled in by adolescent dinosaurs, as in, they would have gone after completely different prey prior to achieving their adult size. So, maybe short arms weren't so short, compared to the rest of the animal, in adolescence and having a different shape may have helped it hunt a different prey as an adolescent. Has anyone ever found an adolescent T. rex fossil? Because that could either aid or destroy my theory completely.
